subject: RE: [junit] Reporting more then 1 failed assertion per test
msgSnippet: In the collection framework when creating a sorted set a Comparator is passed in as an argument.  If the Comparator argument is null the compareTo() on the
messageBody:
In the collection framework when creating a sorted set a Comparator is
passed in as an argument. If the Comparator argument is null the
compareTo() on the elements is called.

I am not sure what use an assertGreaterThan( Collection, Collection)
makes much sense. In mathematics it's not possible to say one vector
is greater than another, unless they are projected onto a given axis.
This is not really possible on your average collection of objects.

I think the only two useful cases are...

assertEquals(Collection, Collection);
assertEquals(Collection, Collection, Comparator );

Passing in a null Comparator to the second method would behave like when
passing a Comparator to a sorted set, equals() method (or compareTo())
would be called on the elements.


Dave


-----Original Message-----
From: Jason Rogers [mailto:jason.rogers@...]
Sent: 25 July 2001 19:29
To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
Subject: RE: [junit] Reporting more then 1 failed assertion per test


You are right. And as I recall, we have tested for that case in our
code as
well. How would the framework know when to use a comparator or not?
Have
something like the following? Seems quirky... but this is what working
on 4
hours of sleep can do :)

assertEquals(expectedCollection, actualCollection)
assertComparesGreaterThanZero(expectedCollection, actualCollection)
assertComparesLessThanZero(expectedCollection, actualCollection)
assertComparesZero(expectedCollection, actualCollection)

-Jason

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Vladimir Bossicard [mailto:vladimir@...]
> Sent: Wednesday, July 25, 2001 12:36 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] Reporting more then 1 failed
> assertion per test
>
>
> >
> >
> >How would this complete list help you any more than the
> simple fact that the
> >arrays were not of the same length? Given that I
> expected them to contain
> >the same number of elements, the most valuable
> information to me would be
> >that they were of different lengths, not which elements
> were/were not
> >present.
> >
> I partially don't agree. I think that comparing vectors
> should tell you
> if the elements are equals. If your testing a sort
> algorythm, you want
> to know if elements of the result vector are in the right
> position.
> This request (assertEquals do array properly) has been
> expressed by
> many people and I think that it should be included in JUnit.
>
> But I'm against the "soft warning" idea. Don't see the
> added value there.
>
> -Vladimir
